articles.headline: A Gold Rush of Subsidies in Clean Energy Search
articles.snippet: Renewable energy has received exceptional help from the government. That is ending, but some say it has been unnecessary.
articles.abstract: Renewable energy has received exceptional help from the government. That is ending, but some say it has been unnecessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Halfway between Los Angeles and San Francisco, on a former cattle ranch and gypsum mine, NRG Energy is building an engineering marvel: a compound of nearly a million solar panels that will produce enough electricity to power about 100,000 homes.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Copter Crash Kills a Leader in Mexico’s Drug Fight
articles.snippet: The death of Francisco Blake Mora, the interior minister, was another blow to Mexico’s anti-drug campaign.
articles.abstract: The death of Francisco Blake Mora, the interior minister, was another blow to Mexico’s anti-drug campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A helicopter crash killed Mexico’s second-most-powerful official and seven others on Friday, dealing yet another blow to the country’s battle against a drug-and-crime scourge and leaving a battered nation in shock.

articles.headline: Batteries in Electric Cars Examined After Chevy Volt Fire
articles.snippet: Federal regulators said they were looking at lithium-ion batteries used in electric cars after a Chevrolet Volt that had undergone a crash test caught fire.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators said they were looking at lithium-ion batteries used in electric cars after a Chevrolet Volt that had undergone a crash test caught fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Federal safety regulators said Friday that they were examining lithium-ion batteries used in electric cars because a Chevrolet Volt ignited three weeks after it underwent a crash test.

articles.headline: Future Farmers Look Ahead
articles.snippet: The Future Farmers of America, which prepares students for viable careers, has gone beyond its roots in agriculture, adding fields like genetics and logistics.
articles.abstract: The Future Farmers of America, which prepares students for viable careers, has gone beyond its roots in agriculture, adding fields like genetics and logistics.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Gamaliel Rizzo grew up in a brownstone apartment in Brooklyn and is studying to become a doctor. Still, he spent his high school years learning how to raise chinchillas, goats and alpaca and growing radishes, sunflowers and cilantro. He even worked on a dairy farm in the summer, all as a member of the Future Farmers of America.

articles.headline: Airbnb’s Lodging Gets Tested, Yielding a Mixed Bag
articles.snippet: The company matching travelers with people willing to rent out a home or a bed isn’t perfect, but it is economical.
articles.abstract: The company matching travelers with people willing to rent out a home or a bed isn’t perfect, but it is economical.
articles.lead_paragraph: For any fan of disruptive consumer technologies, watching Airbnb’s rise has been all sorts of fun.

articles.headline: Power Broker Savors a Victory in San Francisco
articles.snippet: Rose Pak, a savvy networker among San Francisco’s Chinese voters, is said to have played a prime role in electing the city’s first Chinese-American mayor.
articles.abstract: Rose Pak, a savvy networker among San Francisco’s Chinese voters, is said to have played a prime role in electing the city’s first Chinese-American mayor.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Perhaps no one took more pleasure in the city’s first election of a Chinese-American mayor than Rose Pak.

articles.headline: A Bid to Get Film Lovers Not to Rent
articles.snippet: In an effort to make owning more compelling than renting, big movie studios are backing a free service that will allow people to buy a film once and watch it on any device.
articles.abstract: In an effort to make owning more compelling than renting, big movie studios are backing a free service that will allow people to buy a film once and watch it on any device.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood has had enough of the sharp consumer shift toward renting movies through Netflix. Desperate to raise home entertainment profits, studios want people to start buying movies outright again, either digitally or on little silver discs.

articles.headline: Plan Would Delay Sales of Generic for Lipitor
articles.snippet: Pfizer is offering to give discounts on Lipitor to pharmacists who keep filling prescriptions with the name-brand drug once generic competition begins.
articles.abstract: Pfizer is offering to give discounts on Lipitor to pharmacists who keep filling prescriptions with the name-brand drug once generic competition begins.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest introduction of a generic drug in pharmaceutical history is being met with tough business strategies by Pfizer and pharmacy benefit companies, according to recent letters to pharmacists.

articles.headline: Europe’s Woes Pose New Peril to Recovery in the U.S.
articles.snippet: United States policy makers are warning that continued financial tumult in Europe could hurt exports and further erode American consumer confidence.
articles.abstract: United States policy makers are warning that continued financial tumult in Europe could hurt exports and further erode American consumer confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the second time in two years, European debt troubles threaten to slow the momentum of the fragile recovery in the United States.

articles.headline: On Campus, a Law Enforcement System to Itself
articles.snippet: The Penn State scandal is emblematic of a parallel judicial universe favoring college athletes.
articles.abstract: The Penn State scandal is emblematic of a parallel judicial universe favoring college athletes.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the body of an Eastern Michigan University freshman was found in her dorm room in December 2006, naked from the waist down with a pillow over her head, the chief of the university police said there was “no reason to suspect foul play,” and let her parents believe she had died of natural causes.

articles.headline: Arab League Votes to Suspend Syria Over Crackdown
articles.snippet: The decision, which called for Syria to end its crackdown on protesters, was a blow to a nation that prides itself as a powerhouse of Arab nationalism.
articles.abstract: The decision, which called for Syria to end its crackdown on protesters, was a blow to a nation that prides itself as a powerhouse of Arab nationalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Arab League moved to suspend Syria’s membership on Saturday, accusing the government of President Bashar al-Assad of defying an agreement to stop the violent repression of demonstrators, and it threatened economic and political sanctions if he did not comply.

articles.headline: Spotlight Fixed on Geithner, a Man Obama Fought to Keep
articles.snippet: For President Obama, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner has been the indispensable economic adviser who has outlasted every other member of the original inner circle.
articles.abstract: For President Obama, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner has been the indispensable economic adviser who has outlasted every other member of the original inner circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As friends, donors, cabinet members and celebrities like Tom Hanks, Jay-Z and Stevie Wonder partied at the White House one evening last August to celebrate President Obama’s 50th birthday, the president tapped a lesser-known guest on the shoulder.

articles.headline: Dear Committee: Main Street Says Look at Pensions
articles.snippet: One way to cut government spending is to stop reimbursing contractors for the cost of pensions and other retirement benefits.
articles.abstract: One way to cut government spending is to stop reimbursing contractors for the cost of pensions and other retirement benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE so-called supercommittee in Congress has until Nov. 23 to find more than a trillion dollars of new savings in the federal budget.

articles.headline: Nuns Who Won’t Stop Nudging
articles.snippet: Long before Occupy Wall Street, the Sisters of St. Francis were quietly staging an occupation of their own, and have become one of the most surprising groups of corporate activists.
articles.abstract: Long before Occupy Wall Street, the Sisters of St. Francis were quietly staging an occupation of their own, and have become one of the most surprising groups of corporate activists.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASTON, Pa.

articles.headline: Even as Governments Act, Time Runs Short for Euro
articles.snippet: A growing consensus about the urgency of the euro crisis finally brought some action from Italy and Greece, but there is still much that can go wrong.
articles.abstract: A growing consensus about the urgency of the euro crisis finally brought some action from Italy and Greece, but there is still much that can go wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The window of opportunity to save the euro is rapidly closing, as the sovereign debt crisis erodes the solvency of Europe’s banks and drives up borrowing rates for even once rock-solid countries like France.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: A Town Creates Its Own Department Store
articles.snippet: When the only department store in Saranac Lake, N.Y., closed down, residents did something unusual: they decided to raise capital to open their own department store.
articles.abstract: When the only department store in Saranac Lake, N.Y., closed down, residents did something unusual: they decided to raise capital to open their own department store.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.

articles.headline: Animal McMansion: Students Trade Dorm for Suburban Luxury
articles.snippet: The downturn in the real estate market in Merced, Calif., has presented an unusual housing opportunity for thousands of students attending the University of California.
articles.abstract: The downturn in the real estate market in Merced, Calif., has presented an unusual housing opportunity for thousands of students attending the University of California.
articles.lead_paragraph: MERCED, Calif. — Heather Alarab, a junior at the University of California, Merced, and Jill Foster, a freshman, know that their sudden popularity has little to do with their sparkling personalities, intelligence or athletic prowess.

articles.headline: After a Romney Deal, Profits and Then Layoffs
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s business career is a cornerstone of his campaign. But his brand of capitalism had human costs and some messy financial consequences.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s business career is a cornerstone of his campaign. But his brand of capitalism had human costs and some messy financial consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the green-hued yardsticks of Wall Street, the 1990s buyout of an Illinois medical company by Mitt Romney’s private equity firm was a spectacular success.

articles.headline: France Keeps a Watchful Eye on Turmoil in Italy
articles.snippet: Italy has replaced Greece as the focus of anxiety in Europe’s debt crisis, but investors are also worried over the outlook for France.
articles.abstract: Italy has replaced Greece as the focus of anxiety in Europe’s debt crisis, but investors are also worried over the outlook for France.
articles.lead_paragraph: First it was Athens. Then Rome. Could Paris be next?
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Reality TV’s Instant Stars Populate a Magazine
articles.snippet: The new magazine Reality Weekly appears to have both supply and demand working in its favor. The public enjoys reality television, and the stars fall over themselves to be covered.
articles.abstract: The new magazine Reality Weekly appears to have both supply and demand working in its favor. The public enjoys reality television, and the stars fall over themselves to be covered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reality television stars tend to lack certain attributes: discretion, shame, gainful employment. One thing they don’t seem to want for is exposure.

articles.headline: Newspapers’ Digital Apostle
articles.snippet: One of the biggest newspaper chains in America is run by John Paton, who thinks that print is, if not exactly dead, dying a lot faster than anyone thought.
articles.abstract: One of the biggest newspaper chains in America is run by John Paton, who thinks that print is, if not exactly dead, dying a lot faster than anyone thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, John Paton met with executives of the MediaNews Group, the second-largest newspaper chain by circulation in the country, home to papers like The Denver Post, The Detroit News, The Salt Lake Tribune and a broad swath of dailies throughout California, including The San Jose Mercury News.

articles.headline: When Sites Drag the Unwitting Across the Web
articles.snippet: The social media site Klout has caused a stir with its culling of information about individuals, including children, from publicly available sources online.
articles.abstract: The social media site Klout has caused a stir with its culling of information about individuals, including children, from publicly available sources online.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Can an online algorithm track down your child?

articles.headline: Banks Quietly Ramping Up Costs to Consumers
articles.snippet: Facing a reaction from an angry public and heightened scrutiny from regulators, banks are turning to all sorts of fees that fly under the radar.
articles.abstract: Facing a reaction from an angry public and heightened scrutiny from regulators, banks are turning to all sorts of fees that fly under the radar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as Bank of America and other major lenders back away from charging customers to use their debit cards, many banks have been quietly imposing other new fees.

articles.headline: Felons Finding It Easy to Regain Gun Rights
articles.snippet: Decades of lobbying have loosened laws, allowing felons to regain gun rights often with little or no review.
articles.abstract: Decades of lobbying have loosened laws, allowing felons to regain gun rights often with little or no review.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February 2005, Erik Zettergren came home from a party after midnight with his girlfriend and another couple. They had all been drinking heavily, and soon the other man and Mr. Zettergren’s girlfriend passed out on his bed. When Mr. Zettergren went to check on them later, he found his girlfriend naked from the waist down and the other man, Jason Robinson, with his pants around his ankles.

articles.headline: Deficit Panel Seeks to Defer Details on Raising Taxes
articles.snippet: The Congressional deficit reduction panel is hoping to strike an accord on revenue levels but delay tough decisions on raising taxes until next year.
articles.abstract: The Congressional deficit reduction panel is hoping to strike an accord on revenue levels but delay tough decisions on raising taxes until next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a little over a week left to reach a deal, members of the Congressional deficit reduction panel are looking for an escape hatch that would let them strike an accord on revenue levels but delay until next year tough decisions about exactly how to raise taxes.

articles.headline: Health Law Puts Focus on Limits of Federal Power
articles.snippet: If the Supreme Court, as early as Monday, agrees to be the final arbiter on President Obama’s health care law, it will face the question of what the government can force people to do.
articles.abstract: If the Supreme Court, as early as Monday, agrees to be the final arbiter on President Obama’s health care law, it will face the question of what the government can force people to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the federal government can require people to purchase health insurance, what else can it force them to do? More to the point, what can’t the government compel citizens to do?

articles.headline: Hispanics Reviving Faded Towns on the Plains
articles.snippet: Hispanics are offsetting the decline in the white population in many smallest heartland communities.
articles.abstract: Hispanics are offsetting the decline in the white population in many smallest heartland communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: ULYSSES, Kan. — Change can be unsettling in a small town. But not long ago in this quiet farming community, with its familiar skyline of grain elevators and church steeples, the owner of a new restaurant decided to acknowledge the community’s diversity by adding some less traditional items to her menu. Cheeseburgers. French fries. Chicken-fried steak.

articles.headline: Chelsea Clinton to Report for NBC
articles.snippet: The former president’s daughter will be a special correspondent, focusing on reports for the “Making a Difference” series on “NBC Nightly News.”
articles.abstract: The former president’s daughter will be a special correspondent, focusing on reports for the “Making a Difference” series on “NBC Nightly News.”
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC announced Monday that it has hired Chelsea Clinton to become a full-time special correspondent for NBC News.

articles.headline: Google’s Lab of Wildest Dreams
articles.snippet: At Google X, a clandestine lab that many employees do not know exists, engineers and robotics experts are tackling a list of 100 shoot-for-the-stars ideas that eventually might not seem so far-fetched.
articles.abstract: At Google X, a clandestine lab that many employees do not know exists, engineers and robotics experts are tackling a list of 100 shoot-for-the-stars ideas that eventually might not seem so far-fetched.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — In a top-secret lab in an undisclosed Bay Area location where robots run free, the future is being imagined.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Fire Aside, Other Kindles Also Shine
articles.snippet: Three new Kindle e-book readers from Amazon fall short of full-featured tablets, but they have much to offer at comparatively low prices.
articles.abstract: Three new Kindle e-book readers from Amazon fall short of full-featured tablets, but they have much to offer at comparatively low prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you think that the pace of technological progress is already too fast, you’d better not look at e-book readers. You’ll get whiplash.

articles.headline: Justices to Hear Health Care Case as Race Heats Up
articles.snippet: The justices agreed to hear a challenge to the 2010 health care overhaul law, setting the stage for a ruling in the midst of the 2012 presidential race.
articles.abstract: The justices agreed to hear a challenge to the 2010 health care overhaul law, setting the stage for a ruling in the midst of the 2012 presidential race.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a challenge to the 2010 health care overhaul law, President Obama’s signature legislative achievement, setting the stage for oral arguments by March and a decision in late June as the 2012 presidential campaign enters its crucial final months.
